data.title: Rackspace outlines 6% private cloud revenue growth target for 2026 as AI demand accelerates
data.description:
Earnings Call Insights: Rackspace Technology, Inc. (RXT) Q4 2025

Management View

  • CEO Gajen Kandiah emphasized a sharpened strategy in response to the market's shift towards AI at scale within enterprise systems, stating "Organizations now expect AI to deliver returns on their investment. As a result, they are moving beyond isolated AI experiments to operating AI at scale inside core enterprise systems." Kandiah highlighted a "private cloud renaissance," noting accelerating demand for governed, private, and hybrid architectures as AI moves into data-sensitive and regulated workloads.

  • Kandiah described a strategic pivot to a platform engineering model, focusing on forward-deployed engineers embedded within customer environments, with a particular partnership and delivery emphasis on Palantir's Foundry and AIP platforms. He stated, "We have 30 Palantir-trained platform engineers today and plan to scale to over 250 in the next 12 months."

  • Leadership changes were implemented to address what Kandiah called an "execution challenge," bringing in executives with deep operational and delivery expertise.

  • Kandiah announced anchor partnerships with VMware, Rubrik, and Palantir, each representing a layer within Rackspace's AI-focused ecosystem.

  • On guidance, Kandiah said, "We expect private cloud revenue to grow 6% at the midpoint year-over-year, the first sustained growth in many years, anchored by large multiyear enterprise engagements."

  • CFO Mark Marino stated, "First, we beat revenue guidance, driven by public cloud outperformance. Second, non-GAAP operating profit came in at $41 million, above the high end of our range with margins up 120 basis points sequentially. Third, we ended the year with $397 million in total liquidity and $60 million in cash flow from operations for the quarter, a strong foundation heading into 2026."

Outlook

  • Annual GAAP revenue for 2026 is expected to be between $2.6 billion and $2.7 billion, down 1% year-over-year at the midpoint.

  • Private cloud revenue is projected at $1.25 billion to $1.75 billion, up 6% year-over-year at the midpoint, with growth anticipated to be balanced across the year as large healthcare and regulated deployments move into production.

  • Public cloud revenue is anticipated at $1.575 billion to $1.625 billion, down 6% year-over-year at the midpoint, with services revenue expected to grow mid- to high teens, excluding a planned exit from a low-margin government contract.

  • Non-GAAP operating profit is projected between $160 million and $170 million, representing growth of 31% at the midpoint, and non-GAAP loss per share in the range of $0.15 to $0.20.

  • The company is shifting to an annual guidance framework to reflect the increasing variability in quarterly revenue timing due to large deal implementations.

Financial Results

  • Q4 GAAP revenue was $683 million, with non-GAAP gross profit margin at 18.1%, down sequentially due to lower private cloud revenue and a higher mix of public cloud infrastructure.

  • Non-GAAP operating profit was $41 million with a non-GAAP operating profit margin of 6%.

  • Non-GAAP loss per share was $0.01.

  • Cash flow from operations was $60 million, and free cash flow was $56 million for the quarter.

  • Private cloud revenue came in at $241 million, below guidance due to a slower-than-expected ramp of a healthcare contract; public cloud revenue was $442 million, exceeding guidance with services revenue growing 28% year-over-year.

  • Segment margins declined in private cloud but improved in public cloud due to operational efficiencies.

Q&A

NOT_APPLICABLE: The transcript does not contain any analyst questions or management Q&A exchanges.

Sentiment Analysis

  • Analyst sentiment cannot be determined as there were no analyst questions or commentary in the transcript.

  • Management's tone during the prepared remarks was confident and forward-looking, frequently emphasizing execution, "We are building a platform-engineering model, forward-deployed engineers embedded in the customer environments, working on the platforms where enterprise AI actually runs... That capability sits on a foundation that took 25 years to build." There were frequent expressions of confidence such as "I'm confident in this team, this model and this moment for our company."

  • Compared to the previous quarter, management's tone has shifted from cautious optimism to a more assertive and detailed articulation of strategic pivots, leadership changes, and execution plans.

Quarter-over-Quarter Comparison

  • The current quarter revealed a more detailed and actionable AI strategy, with a specific focus on platform engineering, embedded delivery, and scaling Palantir-trained engineers, compared to the previous quarter's broader discussion of AI opportunities.

  • Guidance language shifted from quarterly to annual, reflecting longer deployment cycles and greater revenue visibility.

  • The previous quarter highlighted stabilization in private cloud and initial AI service launches, while the current quarter sets a specific growth target for private cloud and frames AI as a core growth driver.

  • Analysts' sentiment in the previous quarter was not available due to no Q&A; the same lack of interaction is present this quarter.

  • Management's confidence and specificity have increased, notably regarding operational execution and leadership alignment for the new strategy.

Risks and Concerns

  • The slower-than-expected ramp of a large healthcare contract resulted in private cloud revenue landing below guidance.

  • Management noted that quarterly revenue timing will be increasingly influenced by large deal migration and deployment schedules, introducing variability into results.

  • The company is proactively transitioning away from lower-margin infrastructure resale engagements in public cloud, which contributes to the anticipated decline in that segment's revenue.

  • Management is focused on mitigating risks through operational discipline, leadership changes, and by emphasizing recurring, high-value engagements.

Final Takeaway

Rackspace Technology enters 2026 positioning itself as the infrastructure and operations backbone for enterprise AI, targeting 6% private cloud revenue growth and a robust expansion of its platform engineering delivery model. Management has implemented leadership changes to drive execution, is scaling its strategic partnerships, and is shifting its guidance framework to emphasize long-term, durable growth over short-term variability. The company identifies AI, healthcare, and regulated industries as primary growth vectors and expects improved revenue predictability as large engagements ramp throughout the coming year.

Read the full Earnings Call Transcript

data.title: Ormat expects 14.6% revenue growth in 2026 while expanding PPA portfolio and EGS initiatives
data.description:
Earnings Call Insights: Ormat Technologies (ORA) Q4 2025

Management View

  • CEO Doron Blachar highlighted that "2025 was a strong year for Ormat. Revenue increased 12.5% to approximately $990 million and adjusted EBITDA improved by 5.7% to $582 million." He underscored improved performance in the Product and Energy Storage segments, emphasizing higher energy rates in the PJM market and the commissioning of new storage projects. Blachar announced the commissioning of Arrowleaf in California, the acquisition of the Hoku project in Hawaii, and winning a geothermal tender in Indonesia. He detailed securing approximately 200 megawatts of new PPAs, including a 15-year, 150-megawatt agreement supporting Google's data center and a 20-year, 13-megawatt PPA with Switch. He noted, "We also negotiated 2 blend and extend contracts totaling approximately 40 megawatts pending final approval, which will enable us to realize higher energy rates starting as early as 2027."

  • CFO Assaf Ginzburg stated, "Total revenues for 2025 were $989.6 million, up 12.5% year-over-year. Fourth quarter revenue was $276 million, up 19.6% versus the prior year period." He noted the impact of curtailments and asset impairments on net income but pointed to strong growth in the Product and Energy Storage segments. Ginzburg added, "We expect our total capital expenditure for 2026 to be $675 million... Following the sale of our Topp 2 plant in New Zealand during the first quarter for approximately $100 million, we expect the net investment to be around $575 million."

Outlook

  • Ormat projects 2026 revenue of $1,110 million to $1,160 million, reflecting a midpoint increase of 14.6% year-over-year. Electricity segment revenues are expected between $715 million and $730 million, Product segment revenues between $300 million and $320 million, and Energy Storage revenues between $95 million and $110 million. Adjusted EBITDA is expected to rise to a range of $615 million to $645 million, an increase of approximately 8.2% at the midpoint. Management described the guidance as underpinned by "strong momentum in geothermal development and the accelerated exploration efforts."

Financial Results

  • Fourth quarter revenue reached $276 million, up 19.6% versus the prior year period. Fourth quarter gross profit was $78.8 million, up 7.2%. Net income attributable to stockholders for the fourth quarter was $31.4 million or $0.50 per diluted share. Full year net income was $123.9 million or $2.02 per diluted share. Adjusted net income for the fourth quarter was $41.8 million or $0.67 per diluted share. Adjusted EBITDA for the fourth quarter was $158.7 million, a 9.1% increase. Cash and cash equivalents ended at $281 million and total available liquidity was $680 million. The company declared a quarterly dividend of $0.12 per share and expects to maintain this payout for the next three quarters.

Q&A

  • Justin Clare, ROTH Capital Partners: Asked about further blend and extend PPA opportunities and capacity coming up for renewal. CEO Blachar responded that "we have a few more assets, not too many assets that we can blend and extend," and work has started on the next phase.

  • Clare also inquired about curtailment impact in Q4 and expectations for 2026. CFO Ginzburg replied, "the curtailment in Q4 did lessen... for the full year 2026, we are not expecting more than $4 million to $5 million, maybe slightly higher than that."

  • Hannah Velásquez, Jefferies LLC, questioned the translation of new capacity into segment revenue and curtailment recovery. CEO Blachar clarified that "some of the 100 megawatts that you mentioned is solar," and that new solar capacity has a lower capacity factor, while curtailment is expected to be reduced but Puna prices are slightly lower.

  • Mark W. Strouse, JPMorgan, asked about additional EGS pilot activity and equipment sales timing. CEO Blachar indicated discussions are ongoing but material revenue impacts from EPC contracts would likely be seen after 2027 or 2028.

  • Ben Kallo, Baird, inquired about EGS infrastructure and longer-term targets. CEO Blachar noted, "We are looking at much larger land positions in additional states, not just Nevada and California," and plans to provide updated long-term targets at an Analyst Day in September.

Sentiment Analysis

  • Analysts' tone was analytical, pressing for clarity on curtailment recovery, PPA renewals, EGS prospects, and the translation of added capacity into revenue. There was skepticism around the conservatism of guidance and the pace of EGS commercialization.

  • Management maintained a confident tone in prepared remarks and responded candidly in the Q&A, acknowledging conservative guidance and technological risks. CEO Blachar frequently used phrases such as "we are confident" and "we believe," while CFO Ginzburg provided detailed explanations on financial and operational questions. Compared to the previous quarter, management's tone remained steady, though more cautious regarding guidance.

Quarter-over-Quarter Comparison

  • The current quarter featured the announcement of multiple new PPAs, especially with hyperscalers like Google and Switch, compared to negotiations in the previous quarter. Revenue and adjusted EBITDA guidance were raised for 2026, following upward revisions in Q3 for 2025. Analysts in the current call focused more on the realization of guidance assumptions, curtailment normalization, and EGS progress, while EGS was described as less likely to impact near-term targets in the previous quarter. Management maintained steady confidence but was clearer about the conservatism of 2026 projections due to market uncertainties and pricing dynamics.

Risks and Concerns

  • Management cited curtailment impacts, lower energy rates at Puna, and the technological and economic barriers in EGS development as key risks. CFO Ginzburg stated, "prices in Puna are slightly lower. But... this can change very quickly." CEO Blachar stressed a proactive approach in spreading risk in EGS by partnering with multiple technology providers and seeking broader land positions.

Final Takeaway

Ormat Technologies outlined a year of robust growth, highlighted by strong revenue and adjusted EBITDA gains, new long-term PPAs with major data center operators, and major steps in storage expansion and EGS development. Management anticipates 2026 revenue growth of nearly 15% at the midpoint, supported by a healthy backlog, reduced curtailment expectations, and a growing portfolio of renewable energy projects. The company is positioning itself to address evolving energy demands while maintaining a cautious approach in its guidance and capital allocation strategy.

Read the full Earnings Call Transcript

data.title: Sable Offshore slides as court denies bid to lift injunction blocking pipeline restart
data.description:
Sable Offshore (SOC) -15.2% in Thursday's trading after a tentative ruling from the Superior Court of California for the County of Santa Barbara upheld an injunction against restarting the Las Flores pipeline system that would transport crude from its offshore oil rigs.

Sable Offshore (SOC) is "still pursuing federal pathways toward a restart of its onshore pipeline network, and it has said for quite some time that it didn't view this hearing as being critical in its pursuit of that goal," Roth Capital analyst Leo Mariani said, maintaining his Buy rating on the stock.

Earlier this week, the U.S. Department of Transportation’s Pipeline and Hazardous Materials Safety Administration posted a notice proposing to grant the company a special permit to restart the pipeline.

Sable Offshore (SOC) needs a special permit to operate the pipeline due to a consent decree imposed after a 2015 oil spill that was one of the worst in California's history.

data.title: Perimeter Solutions outlines MMT integration and signals improved earnings power with $652.9M revenue in 2025
data.description:
Earnings Call Insights: Perimeter Solutions (PRM) Q4 2025

Management View

  • CEO Haitham Khouri highlighted "structural earnings power expansion" for 2025, citing the company's shift to more fixed and recurring contract structures, particularly in its retardant business. Khouri stated, "We've transitioned Perimeter towards greater financial consistency. The primary driver is the change in our retardant contract structures, which have shifted from purely volume-based models towards more fixed and recurring structures, significantly reducing our sensitivity to fire season volatility."
  • Khouri also discussed recent acquisitions: "2025 established our M&A strategy with the acquisitions of IMS and MMT, both of which we feel excellent about."
  • On Fire Safety, Khouri reported "Fire Safety delivered a strong year, primarily driven by execution on our value drivers. We continue to win profitable new business, including entry into preventative rail applied retardant in Europe, expansion of our air-based services in multiple geographies and ongoing penetration of our fluorine-free products globally."
  • Addressing operational challenges at the Sauget, Illinois facility, Khouri stated, "During the fourth quarter, unplanned downtime once again materially reduced production volumes and negatively impacted PDI's financial results. More troubling are the recurring safety incidents at and around the plant." He further added, "Our commitment to regaining operational control of this facility is absolute. Until this matter is resolved, investors should expect continued variability in our P2S5 business."
  • On MMT, Khouri said, "MMT recorded approximately $140 million in revenue and $50 million in adjusted EBITDA in 2025. One month into our ownership, initial value driver implementation validates our investment thesis, and we expect MMT's 2026 results to reflect meaningful year-over-year growth."
  • CFO Kyle Sable stated, "Consolidated revenue reached $652.9 million in 2025, up 16%, while adjusted EBITDA increased 18% to $331.7 million. In the fourth quarter, revenue grew 19% to $102.8 million and adjusted EBITDA rose 9% to $36 million."

Outlook

  • Khouri indicated "Looking forward, we will continue to rigorously apply our value drivers and paired with the secular growth drivers aiding our fire safety business, including higher acres burned and expanding air tanker fleet, continued growth in the wildland urban interface, new retardant application methods and the global transition to flooring-free foams, our Fire Safety segment is well positioned for profitable growth."
  • Sable said, "We expect MMT to deliver solid year-over-year growth in 2026 as we implement our operational value driver strategy."
  • Sable also provided long-term assumptions: "We now expect annual interest expense to be approximately $75 million, driven by the MMT acquisition funding, which closed in January. Tax deductible depreciation, amortization and other items are expected to be in the range of $60 million to $75 million annually going forward. Capital expenditures are expected to run $30 million to $40 million per year."

Financial Results

  • Sable reported, "For the full-year, this performance translated to a GAAP loss per share of $1.37 compared to a GAAP loss per share of $0.04 in the prior year. Adjusted EPS for 2025 was $1.34, up from $1.11 last year, representing an increase of approximately 21%. In the fourth quarter, GAAP loss per share was $0.94 compared to GAAP EPS of $0.90 in the prior year quarter. Adjusted EPS for both Q4 2025 and Q4 2024 was $0.13."
  • Fire Safety segment full-year revenue totaled $488.9 million, with adjusted EBITDA at $290.5 million.
  • Specialty Products revenue for the year reached $163.9 million, an increase of 31%, with full-year adjusted EBITDA for Specialty Products at $41.2 million.
  • Sable highlighted, "We acquired Medical Manufacturing Technologies, LLC in January 2026 for $685 million in cash, funded with a combination of cash on hand and the issuance of $550 million of new senior secured notes."
  • Sable added, "We ended the year with $325.9 million of cash and equivalents and an undrawn $200 million revolver. On a pro forma basis, accounting for the closing of MMT and the $550 million notes offering, we were levered 3x net debt to adjusted EBITDA."

Q&A

  • Joshua Spector, UBS: Asked about the fixed versus variable mix in fire retardants and how much is now under fixed contracts. Khouri responded, "We haven't broken out and are reluctant to break out a specific fixed variable split... the consistency and predictability of the cash flows... are dramatically more predictable than they were historically and should actually get incrementally more predictable in '26 versus '25."
  • Spector: Inquired about metrics that should be used to track fire retardant deployment. Khouri replied, "There's no great metric... I still think remains U.S. and North American acres burned. I would just say the percent change in our revenue and EBITDA relative to the percent change in acres burned is just dramatically muted relative to what it was in our historical financials."
  • Spector: Questioned the accretion of $40 million deployed into electro-optical assets. Khouri responded, "We think the product line acquisitions at IMS are higher returning than our typical M&A... the IRRs are very attractive on these acquisitions."
  • Daniel Kutz: Asked about long-term growth prospects across product lines. Khouri stated, "We think there is very solid organic growth throughout our portfolio... Specialty Products segment also has, we think, excellent long-term organic growth potential with strong secular drivers."
  • Kutz: Asked about opportunities in MMT between OEM and aftermarket. Khouri replied, "We feel very good... that all 3 [value drivers] are going to be solidly applicable... I just emphasize the profitable new business opportunity here."
  • Kutz: Inquired about international retardant trends. Sable answered, "We're going to have to wait until March to see what those look like. That said... there's been a long-term secular trend across the globe of having more fires and more intense firefighting activity."

Sentiment Analysis

  • Analysts' tone was generally positive, with Spector congratulating management and expressing optimism for resolution of the P2S5 situation. Questions focused on contract structure, growth prospects, and M&A returns, indicating constructive engagement and interest in clarity around revenue predictability and accretion.
  • Management's tone remained confident and assertive during both prepared remarks and Q&A, especially regarding contract predictability, growth opportunities, and M&A returns. Khouri used phrases like "our commitment... is absolute" and "we are confident we can restore operational discipline" when addressing operational challenges, while Sable emphasized "improved financial stability" and "ample financial capacity to pursue value-creating M&A."
  • Compared to the previous quarter, management appeared more assertive regarding MMT integration and the pursuit of legal remedies at Sauget, with a continued focus on durable growth and consistency. Analyst tone remained supportive but pressed for quantification and specifics on growth and returns.

Quarter-over-Quarter Comparison

  • The current quarter highlighted the integration of MMT and a more detailed discussion of capital allocation and leverage, while the previous quarter centered on the new U.S. Forest Service contract and its impact on revenue stability.
  • Management’s tone shifted from emphasizing contract renewal and operational resilience to a more pronounced focus on M&A, portfolio expansion, and ongoing legal action at Sauget.
  • Key metrics such as revenue, adjusted EBITDA, and adjusted EPS all showed growth compared to the prior quarter and year.
  • Analyst focus shifted from contract structure and fire season impact to the growth contribution of acquisitions, returns on capital deployment, and international expansion opportunities.

Risks and Concerns

  • Khouri specifically cited ongoing operational and safety challenges at the Sauget, Illinois facility: "These are not isolated events. They reflect a pattern of declining operational performance and safety standards under One Rock's ownership."
  • Management warned of continued variability in the P2S5 business until operational control is regained: "Until this matter is resolved, investors should expect continued variability in our P2S5 business."
  • Legal remedies and strategic alternatives are being actively pursued to address these operational risks.

Final Takeaway

Perimeter Solutions management emphasized expanded structural earnings power, improved revenue predictability through contract restructuring, and disciplined capital deployment, particularly with the acquisition of MMT. The company acknowledged ongoing operational risks at the Sauget facility but affirmed its commitment to legal resolution and restoring stability. Management projects continued profitable growth across its diversified portfolio, reinforced by a strong acquisition pipeline and focus on operational value drivers for 2026 and beyond.

Read the full Earnings Call Transcript

data.title: US Physical Therapy outlines $102M–$106M EBITDA target for 2026 as hospital alliances gain momentum
data.description:
Earnings Call Insights: U.S. Physical Therapy, Inc. (USPH) Q4 2025

Management View

  • Christopher Reading, CEO & Chairman, stated that for the year ending 2025, adjusted EBITDA increased $13.2 million, a 16.2% improvement, and net revenue rose 16.3%. Physical therapy and injury prevention businesses grew 16% and 18%, respectively, with a gross profit increase of approximately 21% in PT operations and over 20% in injury prevention. "Operating income improved 18.4%. And I want to remind everyone that these results...were delivered in an environment in 2025 with continued Medicare rate reductions. And in spite of that, across every measure, we delivered progress in a very good year overall."
  • Reading highlighted several acquisitions since the last quarter, including one in the Pacific Northwest, a home care addition, and a new injury prevention team, strengthening the New York City presence. "Very recently, we announced 2 significant hospital arrangements...These strategic relationships will begin a phase-in for our 60 metro clinics and our 10 second market facilities sometime around midyear with an expectation that all 70-plus...clinics...will be under these strategic affiliations by year-end."
  • The hospital partnerships are projected to provide "an enterprise lift for these 2 partnerships of at least $14 million in EBITDA in 2027 and the USPH portion after minority interest of over $7 million."
  • For 2026, Reading outlined initiatives including a continued rollout of ambient listening documentation support, semi-virtualization of front desk and intake, cash-based program expansion, renewed focus on remote therapeutic monitoring, further hospital alliances, and ongoing de novo and acquisition-related development in both PT and injury prevention.
  • Carey Hendrickson, CFO, stated, "2025 was an excellent year for USPH from really every standpoint and particularly from a financial standpoint. And importantly, the efforts we made on key initiatives in 2025...sets USPH up for even greater growth and financial results in 2026 and beyond."

Outlook

  • Hendrickson provided guidance for 2026, stating, "we currently expect adjusted EBITDA to be in the range of $102 million to $106 million for 2026. That includes $2.5 million in incremental revenue related to the Medicare rate increase that went into effect on January 1, 2026."
  • The guidance includes a modest amount related to the hospital affiliations, which are expected to be fully phased in by year-end 2026.
  • The expected contribution of the hospital affiliation agreements is "at least $14 million on a combined basis to our PT revenue and income with a corresponding impact to USPH's adjusted EBITDA of at least $7.3 million."
  • Management expects same-store revenue growth of around 3% in 2026, supported by both visit and rate increases.

Financial Results

  • In Q4 2025, average visits per clinic per day reached 32.7, a record for the company. Total patient visits grew 11.2% year-over-year, with mature clinics seeing a 1.5% increase in visits.
  • Net rate per patient visit increased 1% to $105.76 for the full year, and $106.49 for the quarter, a 1.7% increase from Q4 2024.
  • Physical therapy revenues were $173.8 million in Q4 2025, up $20 million or 13% year-over-year. Physical therapy operating costs totaled $138.6 million, an increase of $12.9 million or 15.3%.
  • Salaries and related cost per visit decreased by 1.1% in the quarter to $62.15, and total operating cost per visit declined to $85.56. Physical therapy adjusted gross margin improved to 20.5% from 18.6%.
  • IIP net revenues increased $2.3 million or 8.7%, with income up $510,000 or 11.5%. IIP margin for the quarter was 17.1%, up from 16.7%.
  • Adjusted EBITDA for Q4 2025 was $24.8 million, up from $21.8 million in Q4 2024. Full-year adjusted EBITDA rose from $81.8 million to $95 million.

Q&A

  • Lawrence Solow, CJS Securities: Asked about hospital alliances and the $14 million EBITDA figure. CEO Reading clarified, "the numbers that we provided do assume current volumes and not additional facilities...there are additional facilities planned."
  • Solow queried wage inflation and mature clinic volumes. CFO Hendrickson responded, "we don't see any particularly high pressure on wages...volumes actually picked up in the fourth quarter on our mature clinics."
  • Michael Petusky, Barrington Research: Asked about non-Medicare pricing and workers' comp volume. CFO Hendrickson stated, "I think we can achieve something in that range, 1.5% to 2% on everything that's not Medicare...workers' comp was 9.7% and the volume...was really right in line with the third quarter."
  • Petusky also asked about injury prevention gross margin trends. CEO Reading explained, "we did sign a couple of big contracts that probably were...more profitability, but maybe a little margin dilutive...had to staff up...ahead of the revenue-generating part."
  • Joaquin Eduardo Martinez, BofA Securities: Inquired about the 2026 guide and deal contributions. CFO Hendrickson said, "we expect our visits and our rate combined to be somewhere around a 3% increase in same-store...we have 2 acquisitions that we included in there, the ones we've made this year already."
  • Constantine Davides, Citizens JMP: Asked about hospital alliance exclusivity and rates. CEO Reading answered, "exclusive, yes...the rate is going to vary by market pretty considerably, just like it does within our own PT portfolio, but meaningfully better."
  • Davides also asked about IIP acquisition capabilities. CEO Reading noted, "injury prevention...has a little bit better embedded organic growth...but there aren't that many companies to go buy."
  • Jack Slevin, Jefferies: Sought margin outlook. CEO Reading: "We've factored some margin improvement in our guidance. This year, we'll see, I think, some modest improvement. Next year...we'll see that accelerate."

Sentiment Analysis

  • Analysts raised multiple questions about hospital alliances, wage inflation, mature clinic volumes, pricing, and gross margin trends, with a focus on sustainability and future growth. The tone was neutral to slightly positive, with direct praise for the quarter and excitement about hospital deals.
  • Management displayed confidence and optimism, frequently emphasizing growth opportunities, the impact of strategic partnerships, and operational efficiency initiatives. "We are excited to close the book on Medicare chapter while having some significant opportunities coming together."
  • Both analysts and management exhibited a more upbeat tone compared to the previous quarter, with less concern over Medicare headwinds and more discussion of growth drivers.

Quarter-over-Quarter Comparison

  • Current quarter focus shifted heavily toward the impact of new hospital partnerships and their expected contribution to EBITDA beginning in 2026 and accelerating in 2027.
  • Guidance language became more specific, with a clear adjusted EBITDA target for 2026 and explicit mention of incremental Medicare revenue and acquisition contributions.
  • Analysts' questions shifted from Medicare headwinds and cost controls to growth sustainability, margin trajectory, and the strategic value of hospital alliances.
  • Management's tone moved from cautious optimism in Q3 to strong confidence and forward-looking enthusiasm in Q4, citing multiple record metrics and successful execution of strategic initiatives.

Risks and Concerns

  • Continued inflationary pressure on salaries and operating costs was mentioned, though management indicated strong cost control measures are in place.
  • Some margin dilution in injury prevention due to staffing for new contracts before revenue realization was discussed.
  • Execution risk remains for the hospital partnerships, particularly regarding the phase-in and integration of new facilities.
  • Analysts sought clarity on the sustainability of volume growth at mature clinics and the impact of large but lower-margin contracts.

Final Takeaway

USPH management emphasized that 2025 marked a year of record results across multiple metrics despite ongoing Medicare pressures, driven by operational efficiencies, strategic acquisitions, and robust demand. The addition of significant hospital partnerships is expected to begin contributing materially in 2026, with an explicit adjusted EBITDA target and multiple growth initiatives underway. Management signaled confidence in the sustainability of cost controls and future margin expansion as new alliances and efficiency projects scale, positioning the company for accelerated growth through 2027.

Read the full Earnings Call Transcript

data.title: Flowco signals $82M–$86M Q1 adjusted EBITDA target as Valiant integration broadens artificial lift suite
data.description:
Earnings Call Insights: Flowco Holdings Inc. (FLOC) Q4 2025

Management View

  • Joseph Edwards, President and CEO, highlighted a strong finish for 2025, stating Flowco "generated $83.5 million of adjusted EBITDA, exceeding expectations." He emphasized growth in adjusted EBITDA for the full year, margin expansion, and robust free cash flow of $63 million in the quarter, which enabled leverage reduction below pre-acquisition levels. Edwards underscored the durability of Flowco's business model and noted that the high-margin rental business continued to drive industry-leading margins in Q4.
  • Edwards announced the acquisition of Valiant Artificial Lift Solutions, describing it as an "attractive valuation" and a move that broadens Flowco’s artificial lift offerings, particularly by adding ESP systems for the Permian Basin and enhancing cross-selling opportunities. He stated, "We believe our expanded offering will enable us to deliver improved customer outcomes while generating attractive returns and durable free cash flow."
  • Jonathan Byers, CFO, reported, "Fourth quarter performance exceeded expectations, reflecting continued growth in our rental fleet and strong performance and profitability across all our sales business units." Byers detailed that Q4 revenue reached $197 million with adjusted net income of $43 million. He noted, "Rental revenue, most of which is recurring, surpassed $110 million for the first time in the quarter."
  • Byers further explained, "Adjusted segment EBITDA margins expanded 110 basis points quarter-over-quarter" in Production Solutions, and that Natural Gas Technologies segment revenue increased 36% sequentially. He provided specifics on capital deployment and projected CapEx for 2026, indicating an expected investment of approximately $115 million, excluding M&A.
  • Edwards also introduced Flowco's initial steps into international markets, stating, "Flowco has signed 2 agreements with partners in the Middle East and Latin America, both of whom will enhance our ability to grow in these important markets."

Outlook

  • Edwards set Q1 2026 adjusted EBITDA guidance at $82 million to $86 million, including approximately one month of Valiant contribution, and described expectations for continued rental and sales strength: "We expect continued incremental growth across our surface equipment and vapor recovery rental fleets, supported by strong utilization and contracted revenue visibility."
  • Management anticipates Production Solutions segment revenue to remain consistent with Q4 2025, and Natural Gas Technologies sales activity to be similar to prior levels. Corporate expenses are expected to increase modestly in Q1.
  • Edwards noted the focus on integrating Valiant with objectives to "capture revenue synergies, leverage our combined expertise to better serve our customers and build upon the solid operational foundation that Valiant team has built."

Financial Results

  • Flowco reported $197 million in revenue and $43 million in adjusted net income for Q4 2025. Adjusted EBITDA was $83.5 million, and free cash flow reached $63 million. Rental revenue exceeded $110 million for the first time.
  • Production Solutions contributed $127 million in revenue (up 1.5% sequentially) and $57 million in adjusted segment EBITDA, with margins expanding 110 basis points. Natural Gas Technologies revenue jumped to $70 million, with adjusted segment EBITDA at $30 million, despite a margin decrease due to a higher mix of lower-margin system sales.
  • Full-year CapEx was reported at $127 million (excluding M&A), with Q4 deployment of $24 million. Annualized adjusted ROCE for the quarter was approximately 19%.
  • The company ended the quarter with $142 million in borrowings on its credit facility and $580 million of available capacity. A quarterly dividend of $0.08 per share was declared.

Q&A

  • Arun Jayaram, JPMorgan, asked about trends between rentals and product sales. Edwards responded that ongoing investment in HPGL and VRU fleets continues to drive rental revenue and margin improvements, and expects this trend to persist in 2026, depending on market conditions.
  • Jayaram also inquired about international growth plans. Edwards clarified they are "early" in expansion, with recently signed partnership agreements in the Middle East and Latin America, describing a "capital-light approach" and leveraging local expertise.
  • Derek Podhaizer, Piper Sandler, asked about the customer response to the Valiant acquisition. Edwards stated, "It's been very positive…we now can truly deliver on what we say we want to do for customers, which is to offer the right solution in their well as they bring it online."
  • Podhaizer followed up on free cash flow conversion with Valiant. Byers explained that Valiant's cash flow conversion is similar to Flowco's, and that Q4's high conversion rate was aided by finishing the capital plan and working capital improvement, but does not expect that pace to continue in 2026.
  • Phillip Jungwirth, BMO, questioned the optimal lift solution for higher-pressure, higher-GOR wells. Edwards answered, "both of those feed straight into our gas lift solutions...the good news is we've got both, and we've got an active dialogue going."
  • Jungwirth asked about ESP penetration in non-Permian markets. Edwards noted Flowco already has a footprint in the Bakken and Midcon, and expects margin profiles to be similar to the Permian.
  • Keith Beckmann, Pickering Energy Partners, asked about further M&A or portfolio gaps. Edwards confirmed a "robust M&A pipeline" and commitment to disciplined, returns-driven evaluation of future opportunities.
  • Beckmann asked about CapEx lead times. Edwards said the typical 6-month lead time remains consistent, with only minor added complexity for ESP supply chains.
  • Jeffrey LeBlanc, TPH, asked about shifts in artificial lift strategies for secondary horizons. Edwards described proactive collaboration with operators to plan for lift changes as wells mature, including hosting artificial lift schools for customers.

Sentiment Analysis

  • Analysts focused on rental vs. sales mix, international expansion, integration of Valiant, and free cash flow, with a generally positive and inquisitive tone. Questions were forward-looking and focused on execution risk, customer reception, and capital allocation.
  • Management maintained a confident tone, emphasizing continued momentum, disciplined execution, and strategic growth. Edwards used phrases like "we are confident in our ability to sustain performance and deliver attractive returns" and described integration and expansion efforts with optimism.
  • Compared to the previous quarter, analysts remained constructively probing, while management's confidence appeared strengthened by the successful quarter and transformative acquisition. The tone in both prepared remarks and Q&A was more upbeat relative to Q3, reflecting a more robust outlook and greater strategic clarity.

Quarter-over-Quarter Comparison

  • Q4 guidance was higher than Q3, with adjusted EBITDA up from $76.8 million to $83.5 million, and revenue rising from $176.9 million to $197 million. The rental revenue milestone of $110 million in Q4 surpassed Q3's $107 million.
  • Strategic focus shifted from integrating the August asset acquisition in Q3 to executing and integrating the Valiant acquisition in Q4, along with new international expansion initiatives.
  • Management's tone moved from cautious optimism to increased confidence, supported by performance and strategic progress. Analysts in Q3 were focused on internal optimization and capital allocation, while in Q4, attention expanded to international growth and market penetration enabled by Valiant.
  • The capital deployment outlook remains disciplined, with a similar investment philosophy, but Q4 guidance included the addition of Valiant and a more explicit international growth ambition.

Risks and Concerns

  • Management acknowledged that international expansion is in early stages, with a capital-light, partnership-driven approach to mitigate risk.
  • Integration of Valiant poses execution risk, but management stressed a disciplined plan and continuity for customers and employees.
  • Analysts queried free cash flow sustainability and margin preservation in new markets, highlighting possible challenges in maintaining performance levels as the business diversifies.
  • Supply chain complexity for ESP systems was noted but described as manageable given Flowco’s experience.

Final Takeaway

Flowco Holdings closed 2025 with strong adjusted EBITDA, record rental revenue, and significant free cash flow that enabled leverage reduction. The acquisition of Valiant expands the company’s artificial lift solutions, enhances cross-selling opportunities, and accelerates international expansion, with the company targeting $82 million to $86 million in adjusted EBITDA for Q1 2026. Management emphasizes disciplined capital allocation and operational flexibility to support future growth, while integration of Valiant and measured global expansion are expected to drive additional value in the coming year.

Read the full Earnings Call Transcript

data.title: Starwood Property Trust to buy back up to $400M in shares
data.description:
Starwood Property Trust (STWD) shares rose 1.3% in Thursday afternoon trading after the real estate-focused finance company's board authorized the  repurchase of up to $400M of its outstanding shares of common stock and convertible notes over a year.

The share repurchase program will be funded through the company's existing cash. As of Dec. 31, 2025, Starwood (STWD) had $499.5M of cash and cash equivalents on its balance sheet. In addition, it had $175K of restricted cash.

As is usual with stock repurchase authorizations, it's up to the company's management on when, if, and how much of the stock it will buy back, depending on market and economic conditions.

data.title: Adtran outlines $275M-$295M Q1 2026 revenue target as fiber and optical momentum continues
data.description:
Earnings Call Insights: ADTRAN Holdings, Inc. (ADTN) Q4 2025

Management View

  • Thomas Stanton, President, CEO & Chairman, stated that "ADTRAN delivered a strong fourth quarter and finished 2025 with solid momentum. Our quarterly results reflected higher demand and strong execution with revenue above the high end of our original outlook, overcoming typical year-end seasonality." He highlighted that all three business categories achieved sequential and year-over-year growth, with U.S. revenue up 31% year-over-year and 14% sequentially. Non-U.S. revenue grew 12% year-over-year and declined 3% sequentially, aligning with customer order patterns in Europe.
  • Stanton emphasized the performance of Optical Networking Solutions, which grew 33% year-over-year, driven by cloud provider and enterprise customer demand, now accounting for 25% of Q4 revenue. He noted ongoing expansion in the optical customer base as "cloud providers [are] expanding data center capacity and large enterprises upgrading their optical networks."
  • The CEO also reported continued progress in software, with nearly 500 service providers on the Mosaic One platform and over 100 on Intellifi Wi-Fi solutions. Mosaic One Clarity's AI-driven automation is in trials before its planned launch later in the year.
  • Stanton indicated a positive market environment, with "sustained fiber investment across our core markets" and growing demand for automation and software in high-capacity networks. He added, "We delivered a strong Q4 with solid financial results and execution and healthy core -- and healthy cash flows."
  • Stanton stated that the company strengthened its balance sheet by issuing approximately $200 million of convertible notes and repurchased $46.6 million in ADTRAN Networks shares during 2025, reducing minority interest below 30%.
  • Timothy Santo, Senior VP of Finance, Principal Accounting Officer, Treasurer & CFO, said, "We delivered strong results for the fourth quarter and full year 2025, driven by solid execution and healthy revenue growth. As scale improved, we delivered higher margins, and operating efficiency increased across the business."

Outlook

  • The company expects Q1 2026 revenue between $275 million and $295 million and a non-GAAP operating margin of 4% to 8%, reflecting traditional seasonality and current supply chain dynamics.
  • Stanton noted, "At this time, we are not seeing conditions that change our demand outlook or execution priorities. In summary, we entered 2026 with a positive outlook. Customer trends are favorable in the U.S. and Europe, customer acceptance of products has been strong, and our product offerings and competitive position has never been better."

Financial Results

  • Revenue for Q4 2025 was $291.6 million, up 20% year-over-year and 4% sequentially, exceeding the high end of original guidance.
  • Optical Networking contributed the largest and fastest growth, with revenue increasing by $26.9 million or 33% from the prior year.
  • Non-U.S. revenue represented 53% of total revenue, U.S. revenue 47%.
  • Non-GAAP gross margin increased to 42.5% (up 44 basis points sequentially and 122 basis points year-over-year).
  • Non-GAAP operating profit rose to $18.8 million or 6.4% of revenue.
  • Non-GAAP EPS was $0.16 compared to $0.05 in Q3 2025 and a loss of $0.02 a year ago, with a $0.03 benefit from minority share acquisition.
  • Operating cash flow was $42.2 million for the quarter and $129.8 million for the year. Free cash flow for the year was $60.5 million.
  • Cash and cash equivalents at quarter end were $95.7 million after share repurchases.

Q&A

  • Michael Genovese, Rosenblatt Securities: Asked about U.S. and Europe demand and drivers of revenue growth. Stanton responded that momentum is continuing, especially in fiber-to-the-prem and optical segments, with customer capital being unleashed for bandwidth upgrades and AI-driven initiatives.
  • Genovese also questioned the operating margin outlook range. Stanton replied that the range is "not overly impacting the guidance range" and is consistent with historical practice, with memory and optics supply tightness being managed.
  • Ryan Koontz, Needham & Company: Inquired about optical growth drivers, distinguishing between hyperscale/AI cloud and traditional network demand. Stanton said both contributed, with ICP (cloud) performance stronger than historically seen.
  • Koontz asked about MOFN (hyperscaler-contracted builds with traditional SPs). Stanton confirmed such deals are categorized as carrier business and are adding momentum.
  • Koontz requested an update on U.S. fiber-to-the-home greenfield builds. Stanton described Q4 as "solid," with BEAD funding beginning to flow, which provides budget certainty for carriers.
  • Christian Schwab, Craig-Hallum: Asked about asset sales and leaseback. Stanton said leaseback of the East Tower was on hold due to current cash position, but North/South Tower sale is progressing. Noncore asset sales are being evaluated for value enhancement in the second half of the year.
  • Schwab also questioned key 2026 drivers. Stanton singled out enterprise business strength and EU legislative focus on Huawei replacement, calling it a near $1 billion annual opportunity.
  • George Notter, Wolfe Research: Probed the pace of Huawei replacement. Stanton clarified that while EU directives are recommendations, country-level mandates are stronger and are leading to reduced new Huawei deployments. He estimated the targeted TAM for ADTRAN’s sweet spot products at approximately $850 million in EMEA for 2024.
  • Dave Kang, B. Riley: Queried the seasonality of European Tier 1 telco spending. Stanton recalled it was about 60:40 first half to second half last year, mainly in Access & Aggregation. Efforts are underway to smooth this pattern. Kang also asked about the broadband deployment cycle in Europe, with Stanton stating most regions remain in the early stages.

Sentiment Analysis

  • Analysts were upbeat but pressed for specifics on regional demand drivers, margin guidance, and the pace of European market transitions. Their tone was generally positive, with questions focused on sustainability of momentum and clarity on growth catalysts.
  • Management’s tone was confident and assertive, frequently emphasizing strong execution, positive customer trends, and robust product acceptance. Stanton repeatedly described the environment as positive and highlighted both financial discipline and market positioning.
  • Compared to the previous quarter, both analysts and management demonstrated increased optimism, with less concern over volatility and more focus on growth opportunities, particularly in optical and enterprise segments.
  • Direct quote from Stanton: "We have several multiyear tailwinds in our key market segments."

Quarter-over-Quarter Comparison

  • Guidance increased at the high end for Q1 2026 revenue and operating margin compared to Q4 2025, with a focus on continued leverage and cash generation.
  • The strategic focus shifted more toward software and AI-driven platforms, with greater emphasis on enterprise and cloud customer expansion.
  • Analysts in Q4 placed more emphasis on monetizing noncore assets and the impact of European regulatory changes on Huawei replacement, as compared to previous quarters' focus on operational execution and capital structure.
  • Key metrics such as revenue, gross margin, and EPS improved quarter-over-quarter, while cash flow and working capital efficiency also showed positive trends.
  • Management’s tone displayed greater confidence, underpinned by evidence of sustained momentum, while analysts appeared more encouraged by funding developments and regulatory catalysts in the U.S. and Europe.

Risks and Concerns

  • Management acknowledged ongoing supply chain variability, especially in components such as memory and optics, but noted these are being managed through procurement and pricing mechanisms.
  • There is uncertainty regarding the timing and scale of European telco spending, with efforts underway to smooth spending cycles.
  • Asset monetization activities, including potential building sales and noncore asset divestitures, are subject to market conditions and may not close within the anticipated timeframe.
  • Analysts raised concerns about the pace of Huawei replacement in Europe and the potential impact of legislative delays or shifts in carrier procurement patterns.

Final Takeaway

ADTRAN enters 2026 with strong momentum, as reflected by robust Q4 results, improved profitability, and an optimistic revenue and margin outlook. Management highlighted favorable customer trends, ongoing product acceptance, and significant opportunities in both U.S. and European markets, particularly in optical networking and enterprise segments. The company continues to prioritize operating leverage, cash generation, and strategic asset management to support long-term growth.

Read the full Earnings Call Transcript

data.title: GoodRx expects Pharma Direct revenue growth of at least 30% in 2026 amid shift to pharma manufacturer solutions
data.description:
Earnings Call Insights: GoodRx Holdings, Inc. (GDRX) Q4 2025

Management View

  • Wendy Barnes, President and CEO, emphasized that "the fourth quarter marked a strong finish to the year and reflected disciplined execution across our strategic priorities." She highlighted expansion in direct-to-consumer affordability programs, scaled subscription offerings, and deepened retail pharmacy relationships. Barnes announced, "we moved quickly to translate market change into clear execution across our platform," specifically with the launch of condition-specific subscriptions and the integration of pricing into TrumpRx. She detailed the company's focus on Pharma Manufacturer Solutions, now branded as GoodRx Pharma Direct, and its role as a critical growth engine, stating, "full year revenue up more than 40% in 2025 year-over-year."

  • Barnes noted a strategic shift: "we are increasingly orienting the business around pharma manufacturer solutions as a key growth driver," while retaining the core marketplace as foundational. She also cited the platform's scale, with "the #1 prescription app and nearly 300 million site visits annually."

  • Barnes highlighted a collaboration with Novo Nordisk for the Wegovy pill, stating, "we believe GoodRx accounted for nearly 20% of all Wegovy Pill self-pay fills during a single week in January." She also mentioned partnerships with Pfizer and integration with TrumpRx.

  • On subscriptions, Barnes pointed to "strong early adoption related to our condition-specific subscriptions, particularly around weight loss," and introduced Employer Direct, a new offering targeting employer-sponsored affordability.

  • Christopher McGinnis, CFO, stated, "For the fourth quarter, revenue came in at $194.8 million and adjusted EBITDA was $65 million. This resulted in full year 2025 revenue of $796.9 million, which was up 1% year-over-year." He added, "Revenue from Pharma Direct...increased to $151.4 million, up 41% year-over-year."

Outlook

  • The company expects full year 2026 revenue between $750 million and $780 million and adjusted EBITDA of at least $230 million. McGinnis explained, "Our outlook reflects the decisions we are making to ensure the long-term durability of our business."

  • GoodRx projects Pharma Direct revenue to grow at least 30% year-over-year in 2026.

  • Management anticipates continued acceleration in condition-specific subscriptions launched in late 2025, with weight loss subscriptions expected to contribute more meaningfully in 2026.

  • McGinnis stated, "we expect pressure on prescription transactions revenue in 2026, which is reflected in our guidance."

Financial Results

  • Fourth quarter revenue was $194.8 million and adjusted EBITDA was $65 million. Full year revenue reached $796.9 million, with adjusted EBITDA at $270.5 million.

  • Prescription transactions revenue declined 6% year-over-year to $544 million, attributed to the Rite Aid bankruptcy and lower integrated savings program volume, which impacted results by approximately $35 million to $40 million.

  • Subscription revenue for the year was $83.8 million, down 3%. Pharma Direct revenue was $151.4 million, marking 41% growth year-over-year.

  • GoodRx ended the year with $261.8 million in cash and repurchased approximately 48.9 million shares for $217.4 million.

Q&A

  • Michael Cherny, Leerink Partners: Asked about revenue guidance, unit economics, and re-contracting efforts. McGinnis explained that the decline is driven by "significant revenue coming from Rite Aid and some of our other partner programs during 2025 that will not recur in 2026," a shift of high-cost branded medications to Pharma Direct, and "a decline from unit economics" due to renegotiated lower fees across partners.

  • Payton Engdahl, Truist Securities: Inquired about pharma budget spending. Barnes and Laura Jensen, Chief Commercial Officer, indicated "more of the spending has kind of been pulled forward in our sales cycle," with pharma budgets on the direct-to-consumer side continuing to invest.

  • Lisa Gill, JPMorgan: Asked about the future of the core business versus Pharma Direct. Barnes stated, "the core and what we largely refer to as Rx Marketplace...will always be foundational to our business," but acknowledged a shift toward more durable margins and greater investment in Pharma Direct and Employer Direct.

  • John Ransom, Raymond James: Questioned the impact of take rate and volume on PTR. McGinnis responded, "we're trying to stabilize the underlying volume of scripts," with a focus on renegotiating for long-term durability.

  • Steven Valiquette, Mizuho Securities: Asked about margin pressure and its impact on gross margin and expenses. McGinnis noted, "the cost of revenue is a little higher on...condition-specific subscriptions," and said, "Pharma Direct is a high grower, healthy margin profile, but that's diluted to higher core business margins over time."

  • Additional analysts explored sales and marketing strategy, stability in generic prescription monetization, and volume trends in integrated savings programs.

Sentiment Analysis

  • Analysts raised concerns about revenue guidance, margin durability, and the business model transition, with a neutral to slightly negative tone reflecting skepticism around PTR headwinds and subscription momentum, but acknowledged management's transparency.

  • Management maintained a confident and pragmatic tone in prepared remarks, emphasizing execution, market adaptation, and long-term growth. In Q&A, management was candid about near-term headwinds and used phrases like "we believe" and "we are confident," but also acknowledged, "this is a negotiation of lower fees across multiple partners in our ecosystem."

  • Compared to the previous quarter, both analysts and management displayed heightened focus on the implications of the business model shift and more explicit discussion of trade-offs impacting near-term revenue.

Quarter-over-Quarter Comparison

  • The current quarter marks a sharper pivot toward pharma manufacturer solutions, now branded as Pharma Direct, with explicit guidance for at least 30% growth in that segment versus prior quarters where manufacturer solutions growth was highlighted but less central.

  • Management’s tone this quarter is more focused on long-term strategic repositioning, openly discussing near-term revenue pressures in the legacy marketplace and subscription segments.

  • Analysts shifted from questions about macro headwinds and policy tailwinds in Q3 to deeper scrutiny of margin trade-offs, the durability of new business lines, and the specifics of pharma partnerships in Q4.

  • Key metrics such as Pharma Direct revenue and prescription transaction declines were more pronounced focal points this quarter, with explicit discussion of non-recurring impacts from Rite Aid and integrated savings programs.

Risks and Concerns

  • Management cited the continued impact of the Rite Aid bankruptcy and lower volumes in integrated savings programs as significant headwinds.

  • There are explicit concerns about near-term pressure on prescription transaction revenue due to renegotiated fee structures and the business model transition.

  • Management outlined mitigation strategies, including investment in Pharma Direct, condition-specific subscriptions, and Employer Direct, to drive long-term growth and stabilize volumes.

Final Takeaway

GoodRx leadership underscores that the company is navigating a deliberate transition toward pharma manufacturer solutions and subscription offerings, positioning these as durable long-term growth drivers amid changing pharmacy economics and consumer preferences. While near-term revenue and margin pressures are expected, management expresses confidence in the evolving strategy and the company's ability to leverage its scale, partnerships, and brand to deliver value across the healthcare ecosystem in 2026 and beyond.
